title: Sun opposition Moon
summary: Tension between outward goals and inner feelings. External demands can rub against mood, pushing a choice between performing and honoring what you need. The opportunity is to integrate both instead of swinging between them.

meaning.headline: Outer expression and inner needs face each other directly.

frames.text: Sun–Moon oppositions highlight a split between public-facing duties and private feelings that requires conscious balancing.
Awareness of emotional undercurrents can sharpen decisions if neither side is ignored.
You may notice projections—assuming others are carrying what you’d rather not acknowledge.
Naming the tension reduces reactive swings between doing and feeling.
Conflict between needs and obligations is inevitable or catastrophic.

frictions: Overexposure of feelings in professional settings
Projecting discomfort onto partners or colleagues
opportunities: Letting feelings inform pacing and boundaries
Sharing context so others understand your bandwidth
Aligning actions with what actually feels sustainable

do: Pause to check what you feel before committing.
State both the task and the need it bumps against.
Schedule breaks so obligations do not steamroll you.
Ask for context instead of assuming expectations.
Let honesty guide tone, not dramatics.
avoid: Pretending everything is fine to keep moving
Using mood as the only compass
Dumping emotions on someone who cannot act on them
Assuming people should already know what you need
Swinging from overpromising to canceling last minute

reusable_lines.text: Balance the task and the feeling—both matter today.
Name the tension so it guides you instead of driving you.

forbidden_claims: Predictions of emotional crises or breakups
Deterministic claims about failure or success
allowed_framing: Process framing: this aspect highlights tension to work with
Agency-based language: you can respond intentionally
Contextual framing: plans may need adjustment if feelings are strong
